s.text: Gels were transferred to nitrocellulose membranes (Sigma) and blocked with 5% milk powder in PBS at 4¡C (overnight).
, [ 27, 30] suggest that in IBD, iNOS blocks an early, obligatory phase of inflammation, but perhaps not the chronic phase.
A strong band is detected as MAdCAM-1 transcript after stimulated with TNF-? (20 ng/ml) for 12 h.
(1997) [ 27] reported that acetic acid-induced colitis was more severe in iNOS -/-deficient animals, consistent with a protective role of iNOS derived NO in colitis.

Our data suggest that in this model, endogenous NO (derived from either iNOS or eNOS), does not significantly influence MAdCAM-1 expression, however, both rapid and slow releasing NO donors can potently inhibit the expression of MAdCAM-1 and reduce lymphocyte endothelial adhesion.

Here, we examine the induction of MAdCAM-1 by TNF-?, and evaluated whether endogenous nitric oxide (from eNOS and iNOS), or exogenous NO (from rapid or slow-releasing NO donors) affect the expression of MadCAM-1.

Both a short and long acting NO donor blocked MAdCAM-1 induction, but the slow-releasing NO DETA-NO was apparently at least 10 times more effective than SperNO (on a molar basis).

2), while the long acting NO donor DETA-NO significantly reduced MAdCAM-1 at a only 1/10 the concentration of SperNO needed to reduce MAdCAM-1 expression (10 uM and 100 uM significantly attenuated MAdCAM-1 expresssion).
